description: I've trying to find a good git gui in linux for a long time, but github desktop it is one of the bests, thanks for your work
Made things so much easier, helped me a lot.
"the name org.freedesktop.secrets was not provided by any .service files" when trying to login to clone a repo
Keep me up-to-date for the translations!

GitHub are completely insane to make an Electron app for developers.. and only support Windows and Mac OS officially.

> We have no immediate plans to support an official Linux version, but we continue to evaluate it alongside our other priorities and we know it's important to many people out there. I also know "maybe someday" is a disappointing response and I apologize for that.

This port is a lifesaver
Sign in to Github not working. Just keeps turning.

Couldnt get the github auth flow working.. so the app is useless. 

This is an old version that needs to be updated. current version is 2.9.9-linux2
fixed version is 2.9.12.
I just wanted to say that Sign In works

Integrations for Gnome Terminal, Gnome TextEdit, and default browser worked great out of the box. Do NOT use Flatseal to change filesystem permissions or you will break this.

If you install both VS Code via flatpack, you will need to create a `/usr/bin/code` file with the following content:

```
#!/bin/sh

flatpak run com.visualstudio.code "$@"
```

Tested on Debian Sid and Fedora 36
No problems with sign in and operating

This tool takes away the headaches and issues that came along with the PAT requirments enforced on GH command-line users some-months ago. It automates the whole security process, only requiring that you authorize access to GH. To be honest, I perfer working in a Command-line environment usually, because often-times a GUI will limit a user where a CLI for the same job will enable a user. This tool doesn't feel dibilitating though, and is really easy to use. I really like it, and first used it on windows. I am really happy to see it come to Linux.
its pretty good when it works but currently i can not sign in no matter what i do. Github CLI did it for me tho
